conclusion: To determine the trend of the acceleration of object B during the time interval from 0 to t2, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph for object B.
The v-t graph shows how the velocity of an object changes over time.
The slope of the v-t graph at any point gives the acceleration of the object at that instant.
At t = 0, object B starts with a certain initial velocity.
From t = 0 to t1, the velocity of object B decreases, reaching a minimum at t1.
From t1 to t2, the velocity of object B increases.
From t = 0 to t1, the velocity decreases, indicating negative acceleration (deceleration).
The slope of the curve is negative and becomes less steep as it approaches t1, suggesting that the magnitude of acceleration is decreasing.
At t1, the velocity is at its minimum, and the slope is zero, indicating zero acceleration momentarily.
From t1 to t2, the velocity increases, indicating positive acceleration.
The slope of the curve is positive and becomes steeper as it approaches t2, suggesting that the magnitude of acceleration is increasing.
Initially, the acceleration is negative and its magnitude decreases as it approaches t1.
At t1, the acceleration is zero.
After t1, the acceleration becomes positive and its magnitude increases as it approaches t2.
The acceleration of object B decreases in magnitude until t1, becomes zero at t1, and then increases in magnitude from t1 to t2.
